conversation.text: Hi, I'm going to help you find out how to make cookie cups today
Ok, what cookie dough am i going to need?
The best type is drop cookie mix - it's fine to use store bought mix. Sugar cookie mixes will work too.
evidence: The best type of cookie recipe to use for this method is the drop cookie

conversation.text: What equipment will i need?
One batch of cookie mix should enough to fill 2 mini muffin tins. Spray them with cooking oil or grease them before you start so the cups come out more easily afterwards.
Ok, what should I do with them?
Have you put your oven on yet?
No, I'll do it now. What temperature?
You had best check your recipe, but it's usually around 350'F
evidence: For most recipes, this will be 350°F

conversation.text: Should I make my dough now?
Yes. Make sure you follow the recipe closely.
evidence: prepare the cookie dough according to the recipe

conversation.text: I've done that, now what should i do with it?
Have you finished kneading the dough enough that it will make small balls?
evidence: When you finish kneading the dough together, stop.

conversation.text: Yes, I'm ready to put it in the tins.
Make small balls, about an inch across, and put one in each well of the tin.
evidence: Scoop small balls of dough into the greased muffin tin

conversation.text: I haven't got enough dough to fill both tins
Have you used about 1 tablespoon in each well?
evidence: Plan on using about 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of cookie dough for each well.

conversation.text: No, I filled each well right up.
You only need 1 tablespoon/15ml in each well. I suggest taking some out of each well.
evidence: Plan on using about 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of cookie dough for each well.

conversation.text: Ok, now they've all got a bit in. What next?
Shape the balls so there's a well in the middle and they go about two thirds of the way up the sides of the tins.
Done that. Can I bake them now?
Yes, for about 10 minutes
ok, that's ten minutes, what now?
Are the cups lightly browned on the edges?
evidence: The cookie cups are ready when they are lightly browned on the edges.

conversation.text: Yes, they are. Are they ready?
Yes, they are ready. Before you take them out, have any lost their shape?
Yes, a few have puffed up in the middle.
Before you take them out, use the handle of a wooden spoon to press those ones back down. Then you can take them out.
evidence: press down onto the center of each cup with the handle of a wooden spoon

conversation.text: Lovely. What can I fill them with?
Have they finished cooling yet?
Yes, I've cooled them on a rack.
You can fill them now using a piping bag or a small spoon.
evidence: Use a piping bag or a small spoon to fill the cups.

conversation.text: What could I put in them?
Mainly mini pudding fillings - custard is great, as is whipped cream with sliced stawberries.
evidence: Custard or pudding Mousse No-bake cheesecake Whipped cream and a sliced strawberry

conversation.text: That's really great, thank you for helping me
Thank you for joining me, is there anything else I can help you with today?
No, that's all, thanks again.

procedure.description: There are two main types of cookie recipes: drop cookies and rolled-out cookies. The best type of cookie recipe to use for this method is the drop cookie, where you roll it out into a ball, then drop it onto a baking sheet. You can also use a refrigerated, store-bought recipe. Most chocolate chip cookies will be drop cookies. Many sugar cookie recipes will also work.

procedure.summary: Grease the inside of one or two mini muffin tins with cooking spray.
procedure.description: A single batch of cookie dough will be enough to fill two mini muffin tins. You can cut the dough in half, however, and use it to fill just one mini muffin tin. You should grease the tin even if it says nonstick; this will make the cups easier to remove.

procedure.summary: Preheat the oven and prepare the cookie dough according to the recipe.
procedure.description: What temperature you preheat the oven to depends on the recipe that you are using. For most recipes, this will be 350°F (177°C). Follow your recipe closely. When you finish kneading the dough together, stop.

procedure.summary: Scoop small balls of dough into the greased muffin tin.
procedure.description: Roll the dough into 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) balls, or form them using a cookie scoop. Drop each ball into a well in the muffin tin. Plan on using about 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of cookie dough for each well.

Press the balls into the bottom of each well. Use a wooden spoon handle or your thumb to make a well in the middle of each ball. Press the dough against the bottom and sides of the cup. Only make them go two-thirds of the way up.

procedure.summary: Bake the cups for about 10 minutes.
procedure.description: Keep in mind that the baking time may vary depending on your recipe. The cookie cups are ready when they are lightly browned on the edges.

Sometimes, the cookies will puff out while they bake, and the wells will become smaller. If this happens to you, press down onto the center of each cup with the handle of a wooden spoon. You must do this right after you take the cups out of the oven, while they are still warm and in the muffin tin.

procedure.summary: Remove the cups from the tin and allow them to cool.
procedure.description: Let the cups cool for about 5 minutes first. Invert the tin and let the cups fall out. Transfer the cups to a wire cooling rack and allow them to finish cooling. If any cups are stuck in the tin, pry them loose with a paring knife.

procedure.summary: Use a piping bag or a small spoon to fill the cups.
procedure.description:
These cups are really small, so you won't be able to fill them with large amounts of dessert or ice cream. You can turn them into mini pies and desserts, however. Ideal fillings include:
Custard or pudding
Mousse
No-bake cheesecake
Whipped cream and a sliced strawberry
